Articles.Content:
Not sure if this is a bug or what, so I'll try here first.

So, I started my new Reality Universe, and the first order of business was to launch a satellite in to orbit which was successful. The second order of business is to launch an unmanned sub-orbital, and I figure it would be reasonable to wait 30 days.

Actually it would be reasonable to wait 90 days, but I only have one pad, so 30 will do.

So I go 10,0000 x time warp and count the days going by until I reach 30. I exit the launch pad and end the session.

Upon restart, it says that I am on game day 8.

What the heck?

This could greatly affect launch window timing, but since no one is complaining about it, I must be doing something wrong.

When you hit "restart flight," everything resets to what it was at the moment when you launched the flight the first time. If you want to keep at 30 days, try hitting "space center" or "tracking station" or something like that. Just not "restart flight."

I believe there is a discrepancy between "Earth days" and "Kerbin days", as Kerbin makes a full rotation once every 4 or 6 hours instead of Earth's 24 hours. It screwed me up really bad a couple times when I was trying to time certain things by counting how many days had gone by by just looking at Kerbin.

Because Kerbin is so small and dense, it needs to spin faster to be more "realistic", giving you that extra dV due to the planets rotation and all.

You might want to check out the Kerbal Alarm Clock mod which I can't play without. You can set up certain windows and times to launch and it will keep track of everything allowing you do to simultaneous missions or automatically fast forward to a particular point in time.
Would be nice if KSP had some kind of MJD editor, so you can just enter the MJD and voila, you're ready for launch day.
